instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board - Works but no battery detect
threads.message:
Hi people,

Here I have a strange case from this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. It came from an other shop, and was initially took in charge for battery replacement because it was inflated.

When I took it in charge, The Mac run fine on battery and also on charger when battery unplugged, but It has a charging issue. Three differents battery has been tried, and also battery cable. I can see charging spikes when the Mac is off and battery plugged. It goes to 0,8A for 2-3 secs, and goes to 0A, cycling. The battery pourcentage was shown in MacOS.

Then I found light oxydation on one of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, I replaced it and some caps and R around. No change. With a thermal cam I saw <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> getting hot when charging spikes come, I replaced it. From this point, the battery pourcentage was not shown anymore on MacOS. The Mac can still run on battery and charger.

Then I replaced <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> because of bad reading (15k instead of 4.7k), no change.

I checked current sensors around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, they were fine, I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>, and also <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

This is the last thing I have done on this board, the behavior is still the same, I have a pretty bad understanding of what is going on and why the battery works, but cannot charge and being shown on MacOS.

I really appreciate to have a little help on this one, thank you.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board - Works but no battery detect
threads.message:
The heat applied when you've changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> affected something more on the board.
Or you may have knocked off, or moved components there.

I can't find <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> in schematic.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> is good.

Check voltage and diode mode to ground on SCL/SDA lines; before and beyond <TRANSISTOR>Q6950</TRANSISTOR>.

BTW, if a component gets hot, doesn't mean is (always) bad; there can be some other reason for such behavior.

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board - Works but no battery detect
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos,

Thank you for your reply ! <RESISTOR>R6950</RESISTOR> was missing, probably knocked off as you mention it, and indeed <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR> does not exist on schematics, but it does on the boardview, very strange. On the boardview it is the resistor next to <TRANSISTOR>Q6950</TRANSISTOR>, connected to his pin4. I can't find anything to match with on the schematics, and I am starting to ask my self, how the fuck did I changed this resistance if it is not shown on schematics...

At first I replaced it with a 4.7k first, don't know why I chose this value, it was in fact a 0omh. I replaced it and now it works fine.

Thank you for your expertise, first time I solved an issue through your forum ;)

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board - Works but no battery detect
threads.message:
Glad to hear I helped.

<RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>/11 are just 0 ohm resistors; series protections for T2's SMBUS.
Not figured in schematic, but easy to "guess" the value interpreting the boardview.
